The Sun now faintly streaks the East with gray,</br>And evening dews refresh the thirsty earth,</br>The weary rustic homeward bends his way,</br>To drown the thoughts of past fatigue in mirth.
Now too the plodding cit his shop forsakes,</br>To strive to pass an hour in social joy;</br>But, dead to mirth, to trade alone he wakes,</br>And fraudful gains his groveling thoughts employ.

The deep-read scholar now his mind refines,</br>O'er the dim lamp seeks intellectual light,</br>Brings the rich ores of science from their mines,</br>And spreads them wide, to feast the ravish'd sight.
In close cabal now hungry harpies sit,</br>And study how to swell corruption's flood,</br>Pension vile slaves, for ev'ry mischief fit,</br>And drench their daggers in their country's blood.
The candidate, to enter honour's door,</br>Now sells or mortgages for ready pelf,</br>Buys venal votes as he would buy a whore,</br>Then to some scoundrel statesman sells himself.
Now rogues in senate virtue's charms display,</br>And sordid slaves for heav'n-born FREEDOM roar,</br>Low bend their knees to delegated sway,</br>And sell their country for a "grasp of ore."
The politician now, o'er coffee's steam,</br>In state Arcana seems an adept grown,</br>And while his brains with air-form'd visions teem,</br>He settles Europe's fate, but scorns his own.

The learned fool, whose mind is amply stor'd</br>With loads of lumber, from the fathers brought,</br>Now hears lewd stories at some festive board,</br>Shakes his dull head, and looks as if he thought.
With eager hurry to the ball now fly</br>The light-heel'd coxcomb, and light-hearted toast;</br>While others, graver, to the play-house hie,</br>Where o'er the scene stalks Hamlet's dreadful ghost.
The sons of Belial now in crowds repair</br>To some lewd brothel, where destruction reigns,</br>Imbibe contagion from the venal fair,</br>And purchase transient bliss with lasting pains.
These scenes I shun, nor tread gay vice's halls,</br>Where white-rob'd virtue meets her fatal doom;</br>But, musing in this lone Cathedral's walls</br>I hold my much-lov'd converse with the tomb.
Hail, sacred place!  thou nurse of pious dread!</br>Parent of wisdom!  Virtue's best defence!</br>Here, while with awful reverence I tread,</br>I view with apathy the joys of sense.
On the strong wings of contemplation borne,</br>The heav'n-rapt mind converses with the sky,</br>And whilst she's taught life's empty joys to scorn,</br>She learns that best of lessons — how to die.
O may that lesson ever sway my mind,</br>Glow in my soul, and in my life appear!</br>And may I still to vice's charms be blind,</br>While scenes like these engage my thoughts or ear!
Here sleep the chequer'd characters of life,</br>The wit, the fool, the coward, and the brave,</br>The faithless husband, and the tender wife,</br>The son of virtue, and th' insidious knave.

In this dread place some worthy pair may rest,</br>Whose faithful breasts a mutual flame enjoy'd;</br>But when they thought to be supremely bless'd</br>Grim death stepp'd in, and all their hopes destroy'd.
Th' insatiate miser, whose all-grasping soul</br>Not e'en Golconda's treasures could content,</br>Whom honour could not bind, nor fear controul,</br>Here lies within his narrow tenement.
The pamper'd prelate, void of christian deeds,</br>Who scorn'd the widow's sigh, the orphan's tear,</br>Whose gilded car was drawn by fiery steeds,</br>Now high repast for hungry worms, lies here.

The venal lawyer, in whose hollow mind</br>Fraud rear'd his throne, and craft his engines spread,</br>Who treated truth's sweet voice as vagrant wind,</br>And spurn'd her lore; here rests his recreant head.

And here may sleep some high-born haughty maid,</br>A fair and well-form'd piece of beauteous dust!</br>Whose bright, love-darting eyes e'en hermits sway'd,</br>Though lost her name by time's corroding rust.
The patriot firm, humanity's chief pride,</br>May here repose; whom FREEDOM gladly owns,</br>Who bravely stemm'd oppression's rapid tide,</br>And made proud tyrants tremble on their thrones.
Th' ambitious statesman, who, devoid of shame,</br>Would raise his fortunes on his country's fall,</br>And scorn those joys that spring from honest fame,</br>As he despis'd, is now despis'd by all.
E'en scepter'd monarchs, or some monarch's mate,</br>Kings of an hour, and pageants of a day!</br>Divested here of all their pride and state,</br>Must mix their royal dust with vulgar clay.

Some feeble, headstrong prince may here repose,</br>Too soft for sway, too proud for private life;</br>Who plung'd his kingdom in the deepest woes,</br>Who scorn'd his people, but — who lov'd his wife.
Who banish'd truth and loyalty the court,</br>Who hugg'd rank rebels to his royal breast,</br>Who chas'd true patriots for a fav'rite's sport,</br>And female counsels still esteem'd the best.
Who saw his subjects grievances unmov'd,</br>Who felt no care for pangs they suffer'd long,</br>Who let his servants plunder unreprov'd,</br>Yet flatt'ry told him, he could do no wrong.
Little in great things, and in small things great,</br>High objects he'd despise, low undertake;</br>Tho' legislation's arts he could not treat,</br>Yet plans he could design, and buttons make.
Yet might this prince be good and gracious styl'd,</br>As living princes never want for praise;</br>So tyrant RICHARD flatt'ry's voice term'd mild,</br>And pedant JAMES, the phoenix of his days.
The bard, whose thoughts could soar with rapid force,</br>Beyond the limits of this nether sphere,</br>And bear away the palm in fancy's course,</br>Revels in splendor, while his bones lie here.

And here sleeps SWIFT — Be still, presumptuous thoughts!</br>Dare not in judgment on his fame to sit!</br>Nor say, while thousands sanctify his faults,</br>Hate made the patriot, and contempt the wit.
Yet o'er his grave shall sweetest flow'rets bloom,</br>For fancy's varying rays his pen impress'd,</br>And though defrauded of the promis'd tomb,</br>His image lives within each grateful breast.
The lord and peasant, bridegroom and the bride,</br>In awful silence here their limbs repose:</br>And here lie friendly by each other's side</br>Those who, when living, were the fiercest foes.

Say then, vindictive sons of hate and strife,</br>Down time's vast current who are driving fast;</br>Say, what avail your ceaseless broils through life,</br>Since here your foes and you must come at last?
And you, ye fair!  gay nature's sweetest flow'rs!</br>O heed the counsel of the moral muse!—</br>Let wisdom's lamp enlighten all your hours:</br>Let virtue's landscape limit all your views.
For, ah!  your ebbing sands decline apace,</br>And soon the rav'nous grave his prey will seek;</br>Then shall be fled each love-inspiring grace,</br>Dim the bright eye, and pale the blushing cheek.
Ye sons of wild ambition, what avail</br>Your vain pursuits at restless fancy's cell?</br>Gain all you can, the cold grave will not fail</br>To be the grand receptacle of all.

Yet e'en in death life's tragic farce is play'd,</br>A farce that's borrow'd from the church of Rome;</br>Pride's children, by their rage of pomp still sway'd,</br>Will go in splendor, even to the tomb.
Ah!  what avail the mockery of woe,</br>The costly trappings, and the sable hearse,</br>Whose plumes nod vain ambition to and fro,</br>The sculptur'd monument, and flatt'ry's verse?
Are things like these congenial to the mind?</br>And can they peace in guilty bosoms fix?</br>Can reason in such gewgaws comfort find?</br>Or can they blunt those stings which vice inflicts?
Ah, no.  In torrents when afflictions pour</br>On our bare heads, and, overcharg'd with grief,</br>We sink oppress'd; we feel in that sad hour,</br>Virtue alone can give our souls relief.
Or if, prone stretch'd upon the bed of pain,</br>The good man's pangs his weeping friends deplore,</br>Resign'd, he suffers, scorning to complain,</br>Nor fears his fate when time shall be no more.
Not so the wretch with guilt and fear oppress'd:</br>While to his mind his past offences rise,</br>All hell seems flaming in his tortur'd breast,</br>And all its terrors are before his eyes.
Gloomy despair excludes soft mercy's ray,</br>And while no med'cines can his pangs assuage,</br>Death, like a bloodhound, marks his horrid way,</br>Seizes his victim, and quite gluts his rage.
O for that noble phrensy of the soul,</br>Which mighty SHAKESPEAR, fancy's fav'rite, fir'd!</br>Then should the muse her sacred tome unrol,</br>And paint mens mad pursuit, by vice inspir'd.
Or did I but possess that "reach of thought,"</br>Which gilds thy moral page, O plaintive GRAY!</br>A piece should in invention's loom be wrought</br>To charm to virtue those who'd gone astray.
In vain I wish, in vain I breathe the pray'r;</br>My wish, my pray'r no heav'n-born maid approves;</br>To gain that glorious height I must despair,</br>Nor feel that rage which real genius moves.
But lo!  while thus I pour my artless lays,</br>And stretch my thoughts beyond my feeble reach,</br>Where death his sable, conqu'ring flag displays,</br>I hear, or seem to hear, this awful speech.
"Cease, cease to weep the happy living dead,</br>But to the dead who're living give thy tears;</br>Pray error's children into truth were led,</br>That, void of guilt, they may be void of fears.
"For soon will come the great, momentous day,</br>When all the rich, poor, old, young, wise and fair,</br>Must shake off all their tenements of clay,</br>And to the silent, dreary grave repair.

"Survey the circle of thy much-lov'd friends,</br>Who fall, like Autumn's leaves, beneath death's stroke:</br>E'en now, thy bleeding heart the tyrant rends,</br>And leaves thee mourning like the blasted oak.

"Yet cease — submit; — for all must meet their fate;</br>And know, O man!  whate'er GOD does is right;</br>He makes pale death ope life's immortal gate,</br>And paths of darkness lead to realms of light.

"Thou too, whose thoughts on life's poor drama flow,</br>Whose luxury of sorrow makes thee dumb,</br>Though thou with vigour, youth, and health now glow,</br>Shalt soon a pallid, clay-cold corse become.

"Then when some friend thy humble grave draws near,</br>For splendid tombs are for the great alone,</br>He'll heave one sigh, and shed one passing tear,</br>And read these lines inscrib'd upon the stone.

THE EPITAPH.</br>"Here lies within our parent earth's cold womb</br>What once was man.  The body's heav'n-born guest,</br>Freed from her prison, now expects her doom,</br>With dubious fears, yet humble hope possess'd.
"MORTAL IMMORTALS!  This great truth revere!</br>Virtue begets fair bliss, and foul vice, woe,</br>This our Bard taught; but what his merits were,</br>The last great day alone will fully shew."</br>
